dt: {bc}a quality of something that stimulates the olfactory organ {bc}{sx|scent||}
{bc}a sensation resulting from adequate stimulation of the olfactory organ {bc}{sx|smell||}
{bc}something that emits a sweet or pleasing scent {bc}{sx|perfume||}

pt: {sc}smell{/sc} {sc}scent{/sc} {sc}odor{/sc} {sc}aroma{/sc} mean the quality that makes a thing perceptible to the olfactory sense. {sc}smell{/sc} implies solely the sensation without suggestion of quality or character.
{sc}scent{/sc} applies to the characteristic smell given off by a substance, an animal, or a plant.
{sc}odor{/sc} may imply a stronger or more readily distinguished scent or it may be equivalent to {sc}smell{/sc}.
{sc}aroma{/sc} suggests a somewhat penetrating usually pleasant odor.

et: Middle English {it}odour,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}odur,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}odor{/it} (early Latin {it}odōs{/it}), going back to {it}*od-os-,{/it} s-stem derivative of a verbal base {it}*od-{/it} (whence Latin {it}oleō, olēre,{/it} also {it}olō, olere{/it} {ldquo}to give off a smell, smell (of),{rdquo} from {it}*odere{/it}), going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}3{/inf}ed-,{/it} whence Greek {it}ózein{/it} "to smell, give off an odor," Armenian {it}hot{/it} {ldquo}smell, odor{rdquo} (probably also an s-stem), Lithuanian {it}úodžiu, úosti{/it} {ldquo}to smell, sniff{rdquo}
The length in the Baltic form is attributed to Winter's Law, which is believed to lengthen vowels before an original voiced, unaspirated stop in Baltic and Slavic in certain environments.
shortdef: a quality of something that stimulates the olfactory organ : scent
a sensation resulting from adequate stimulation of the olfactory organ : smell
a characteristic or predominant quality : flavor
